messageBody:
Thanks Jamie,
I got my answer. it is wise to set up for each test.



--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Jamie" <jimbobdobson@h...> wrote:
> I think you want to encapsulate the call to the API that your tests
use only once. Although it is usually wise to set up each
individually test and this is why setUp and tearDown are so handy.
>
> However, it you really want to re-use an object throughout your
tests create them in the constructor. The class that your tests are
in will only be instantiated ONCE by the test framework. Therefore,
if you want to create an object X once and re-use it in all your
tests you can do something like this:
>
> class YourTests extends TestCase
> {
> public YourTests(String name)
> {
> super(name);
> // YOUR SET UP CODE HERE
> TheObjectYouWantToReUse X = new TheObjectYouWantToReUse
();
> }
>
>
> public void testXXX()
> {
>
> }
> }
>
> James Dobson
>
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: rb
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Saturday, January 31, 2004 1:05 AM
> Subject: [junit] Re: Prob. in extending TestCase class
>
>
> I believe that is normal, with or without extending: setUp and
> tearDown get called for every test method. Makes sense
conceptually
> if you think about it: each method is an entire test unto itself,
and
> so needs its own setup.
> r:b:
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "joshi_pranav_p"
<pranav_p_joshi@i...>
> wrote:

> > I am using Junit Framwork for Testing our java product. we
have
> > created 5 testXXX method to test diff. functionality. for all
the
> > method some API call is required,that we have difine in setUp()
> which
> > is same for all 5 testXXX method. now whenever i run the case
It
> > create 5 diff. object of the class and it is calling 5 time
setUp()
> > method for each textXXX call.
> >
> > Can we do it in single call ? How ?
> >
> > Thanks in advance,
> > Pranav.
